enrolled-dateline.#text: Begun and held at the City of Washington on Friday, the third day of January, two thousand and fourteen

congress.#text: One Hundred Thirteenth Congress of the United States of America

official-title.#text: To impose sanctions with respect to the Russian Federation, to provide additional assistance to Ukraine, and for other purposes.

role.#text: Speaker of the House of Representatives.
Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate.

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
Sec. 3. Statement of policy regarding Ukraine.
Sec. 4. Sanctions relating to the defense and energy sectors of the Russian Federation.
Sec. 5. Sanctions on Russian and other foreign financial institutions.
Sec. 6. Increased military assistance for the Government of Ukraine.
Sec. 7. Expanded nonmilitary assistance for Ukraine.
Sec. 8. Expanded broadcasting in countries of the former Soviet Union.
Sec. 9. Support for Russian democracy and civil society organizations.
Sec. 10. Report on non-compliance by the Russian Federation of its obligations under the INF Treaty.

It is the policy of the United States to further assist the Government of Ukraine in restoring its sovereignty and territorial integrity to deter the Government of the Russian Federation from further destabilizing and invading Ukraine and other independent countries in Central and Eastern Europe, the Caucasus, and Central Asia. That policy shall be carried into effect, among other things, through a comprehensive effort, in coordination with allies and partners of the United States where appropriate, that includes economic sanctions, diplomacy, assistance for the people of Ukraine, and the provision of military capabilities to the Government of Ukraine that will enhance the ability of that Government to defend itself and to restore its sovereignty and territorial integrity in the face of unlawful actions by the Government of the Russian Federation.

is an entity—

knowingly manufactures or sells defense articles transferred into Syria or into the territory of a specified country without the consent of the internationally recognized government of that country;
transfers defense articles into Syria or into the territory of a specified country without the consent of the internationally recognized government of that country; or

brokers or otherwise assists in the transfer of defense articles into Syria or into the territory of a specified country without the consent of the internationally recognized government of that country; or

knowingly, on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, assists, sponsors, or provides financial, material, or technological support for, or goods or services to or in support of, an entity described in subparagraph (A) with respect to an activity described in clause (ii) of that subparagraph.

any other country designated by the President as a country of significant concern for purposes of this subsection, such as Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, and the Central Asia republics.

determines that the transaction is in the national security interest of the United States; and

submits to the appropriate congressional committees a detailed report on the determination and the specific reasons for the determination that a waiver with respect to the transaction is necessary and appropriate.

text.#text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), this section, and sanctions imposed under this section, shall terminate on the date on which the President submits to the appropriate congressional committees a certification that the Government of the Russian Federation has ceased ordering, controlling, or otherwise directing, supporting, or financing, significant acts intended to undermine the peace, security, stability, sovereignty, or territorial integrity of Ukraine, including through an agreement between the appropriate parties.

The termination date under paragraph (1) shall not apply with respect to the provisions of subsection (a) relating to the transfer of defense articles into Syria or sanctions imposed pursuant to such provisions.

The funds made available pursuant to subsection (c) for provision of defense articles, defense services, and training may be used to procure such articles, services, and training from the United States Government or other appropriate sources.

header.#text: Assistance to internally displaced people in Ukraine

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit a plan, including actions by the United States Government, other governments, and international organizations, to meet the need for protection of and assistance for internally displaced persons in Ukraine, to—

text.#text: Not later than 30 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate

text.#text: the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives

text.#text: the
The plan required by paragraph (1) should include, as appropriate, activities in support of—

helping to establish a functional and adequately resourced central registration system in Ukraine that can ensure coordination of efforts to provide assistance to internally displaced persons in different regions;

encouraging adoption of legislation in Ukraine that protects internally displaced persons from discrimination based on their status and provides simplified procedures for obtaining the new residency registration or other official documentation that is a prerequisite to receiving appropriate social payments under the laws of Ukraine, such as pensions and disability, child, and unemployment benefits; and
helping to ensure that information is available to internally displaced persons about—
government agencies and independent groups that can provide assistance to such persons in various regions; and
evacuation assistance available to persons seeking to flee armed conflict areas.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall instruct the United States permanent representative or executive director, as the case may be, to the relevant

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and other appropriate international organizations, to use the voice and vote of the United States to support appropriate assistance for internally displaced persons in Ukraine.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

text.#text: The

header.#text: Assistance to the defense sector of Ukraine
Assistance To address the energy crisis in Ukraine

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , shall work with officials of the Government of Ukraine to develop a short-term emergency energy assistance plan designed to help Ukraine address the potentially severe short-term heating fuel and electricity shortages facing Ukraine in 2014 and 2015.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency

text.#text: The
the acquisition of short-term, emergency fuel supplies;
the repair or replacement of infrastructure that could impede the transmission of electricity or transportation of fuel;
the prioritization of the transportation of fuel supplies to the areas where such supplies are needed most;
streamlining emergency communications throughout national, regional, and local governments to manage the potential energy crisis resulting from heating fuel and electricity shortages;

forming a crisis management team within the Government of Ukraine to specifically address the potential crisis, including ensuring coordination of the team’s efforts with the efforts of outside governmental and nongovernmental entities providing assistance to address the potential crisis; and
developing a public outreach strategy to facilitate preparation by the population and communication with the population in the event of a crisis.
The plan required by subparagraph (A) should include strategies to address heating fuel and electricity shortages in Ukraine, including, as appropriate—
procurement and transport of emergency fuel supplies, including reverse pipeline flows from Europe;
provision of technical assistance for crisis planning, crisis response, and public outreach;
repair of infrastructure to enable the transport of fuel supplies;
repair of power generating or power transmission equipment or facilities;
procurement and installation of compressors or other appropriate equipment to enhance short-term natural gas production;
procurement of mobile electricity generation units;
conversion of natural gas heating facilities to run on other fuels, including alternative energy sources; and
provision of emergency weatherization and winterization materials and supplies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: are authorized to provide assistance in support of, and to invest in short-term solutions for, enabling Ukraine to secure the energy safety of the people of Ukraine during 2014 and 2015, including through—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , shall work with officials of the Government of Ukraine to develop medium- and long-term plans to increase energy production and efficiency to increase energy security by helping Ukraine reduce its dependence on natural gas imported from the Russian Federation.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development

text.#text: The
improve corporate governance and unbundling of state-owned oil and gas sector firms;
increase production from natural gas fields and from other sources, including renewable energy;
license new oil and gas blocks transparently and competitively;
modernize oil and gas upstream infrastructure; and
improve energy efficiency.
The medium- and long-term plans required by subparagraph (A) should include strategies, as appropriate, to—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: should, during fiscal years 2015 through 2018, work with other donors, including multilateral agencies and nongovernmental organizations, to prioritize, to the extent practicable and as appropriate, the provision of assistance from such donors to help Ukraine to improve energy efficiency, increase energy supplies produced in Ukraine, and reduce reliance on energy imports from the Russian Federation, including natural gas.

header.#text: Expanded broadcasting in countries of the former Soviet Union

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Chairman of the Broadcasting Board of Governors

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a plan, including a cost estimate, for immediately and substantially increasing, and maintaining through fiscal year 2017, the quantity of Russian-language broadcasting into the countries of the former Soviet Union funded by the United States in order to counter Russian Federation propaganda.

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
The plan required by subsection (a) shall prioritize broadcasting into Ukraine, Georgia, and Moldova by the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty.

header.#text: Prioritization of broadcasting into Ukraine, Georgia, and Moldova

text.#text: In developing the plan required by subsection (a), the Chairman shall consider—
near-term increases in Russian-language broadcasting for countries of the former Soviet Union (other than the countries specified in subsection (b)), including Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia; and
increases in broadcasting in other critical languages, including Ukrainian and Romanian languages.

term.#tail: means the distribution of media content via radio broadcasting, television broadcasting, and Internet-based platforms, among other platforms.

header.#text: Support for Russian democracy and civil society organizations

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall, directly or through nongovernmental or international organizations, such as the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, the

text.#text: The
improve democratic governance, transparency, accountability, rule of law, and anti-corruption efforts in the Russian Federation;
strengthen democratic institutions and political and civil society organizations in the Russian Federation;
expand uncensored Internet access in the Russian Federation; and

expand free and unfettered access to independent media of all kinds in the Russian Federation, including through increasing United States Government-supported broadcasting activities, and assist with the protection of journalists and civil society activists who have been targeted for free speech activities.

header.#text: Report on non-compliance by the Russian Federation of its obligations under the INF Treaty

text.#text: Congress makes the following findings:

The Russian Federation is in violation of its obligations under the Treaty between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the Elimination of Their Intermediate-Range and Shorter-Range Missiles, signed at Washington December 8, 1987, and entered into force June 1, 1988 (commonly referred to as the
This behavior poses a threat to the United States, its deployed forces, and its allies.
It is the sense of Congress that—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: should hold the Russian Federation accountable for being in violation of its obligations under the INF Treaty; and

text.#text: the
the President should demand the Russian Federation completely and verifiably eliminate the military systems that constitute the violation of its obligations under the INF Treaty.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to the committees specified in subsection (d) a report that includes the following elements:

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, and every 90 days thereafter, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: efforts, in cooperation with United States allies, to hold the Russian Federation accountable for being in violation of its obligations under the INF Treaty and obtain the complete and verifiable elimination of its military systems that constitute the violation of its obligations under the INF Treaty.

text.#text: A description of the status of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: assessment as to whether it remains in the national security interests of the United States to remain a party to the INF Treaty, and other related treaties and agreements, while the Russian Federation is in violation of its obligations under the INF Treaty.

text.#text: The
Notification of any deployment by the Russian Federation of a ground launched ballistic or cruise missile system with a range of between 500 and 5,500 kilometers.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of the Director of National Intelligence

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (DTRA), to verify that the Russian Federation has fully and completely dismantled any ground launched cruise missiles or ballistic missiles with a range of between 500 and 5,500 kilometers, including details on facilities that inspectors need access to, people inspectors need to talk with, how often inspectors need the accesses for, and how much the verification regime would cost.
